text: And she said, Who would have said unto Abraham, that Sarah should have given children suck? for I have born him a son in his old age.
text_kjv: And she said, Who would have said unto Abraham, that Sarah should have given children suck? for I have born him a son in his old age.
text_niv: And she added, “Who would have said to Abraham that Sarah would nurse children? Yet I have borne him a son in his old age.”
text_esv: And she said, “Who would have said to Abraham that Sarah would nurse children? Yet I have borne him a son in his old age.”
text_nlt: Who would have said to Abraham that Sarah would nurse a baby? Yet I have given Abraham a son in his old age!”
text_msg: She also said,Whoever would have suggested to Abrahamthat Sarah would one day nurse a baby!Yet here I am! I've given the old man a son!
text_nasb: And she said, 'Who would have said to Abraham that Sarah would nurse children? Yet I have borne him a son in his old age.'
context: Genesis 21:7 is a poignant expression of Sarah's disbelief and joy following the birth of Isaac in Abraham's old age. To understand the weight of her words, we need to appreciate the significance of childbearing in ancient Near Eastern society. Fertility was considered a blessing from God, a source of social status and security, particularly for women. Infertility, conversely, carried a heavy stigma and was often interpreted as divine displeasure. Sarah had endured decades of barrenness, which would have caused her immense shame and diminished her standing within her community. The societal expectation was for women to produce heirs to carry on the family name and inherit property. Without children, a woman's future was uncertain, often dependent on the continued goodwill of her husband or his relatives. The concept of adoption existed, but biological offspring were still preferred. The phrase 'old age' in reference to Abraham wasn't merely descriptive; it underscored the miraculous nature of the event. Menopause in women typically occurs much earlier than Abraham's age at Isaac's birth (around 100 years old). This pushed the boundaries of natural possibility, emphasizing God's intervention. The act of breastfeeding was also significant, demonstrating Sarah's active role in nurturing her son and solidifying her motherhood. It was common in that time for women to breastfeed their own children; hiring a wet nurse was sometimes practiced, but Sarah's willingness to breastfeed signified her deep connection to Isaac.
meaning: Theologically, Genesis 21:7 highlights the themes of divine promise, faith, and God's power over nature. Sarah's question, 'Who would have said unto Abraham, that Sarah should have given children suck?' reveals both her lingering amazement and the sheer improbability of the situation. For years, God promised Abraham descendants as numerous as the stars, but Sarah's barrenness seemed to contradict this promise. This verse underscores the importance of trusting in God's promises even when circumstances appear hopeless. It serves as a reminder that God's timing is often different from our own, and His plans may unfold in ways we cannot anticipate. The birth of Isaac is a testament to God's faithfulness and His ability to fulfill His word, regardless of human limitations. The fact that Sarah conceived in her old age points to God's sovereignty over the natural world. He is not bound by the laws of biology or the limitations of human capability. Isaac's birth foreshadows the coming of Christ, who also represents a miraculous birth and the fulfillment of God's promises of salvation. This event is an example of God's divine intervention into humanity's story and displays God's ability to reverse the natural order, affirming His ultimate authority. Ultimately, the verse is an emphatic affirmation of the Abrahamic covenant and God's unwavering commitment to it.
application: Genesis 21:7 provides several practical applications for modern believers. Firstly, it encourages us to cultivate unwavering faith in God's promises, even when faced with seemingly insurmountable obstacles. Like Sarah, we may encounter situations where our dreams appear impossible or where we doubt God's ability to deliver on His word. However, this verse reminds us that God is not limited by our circumstances or our understanding of the natural world. Secondly, it teaches us to embrace the unexpected ways in which God may choose to work in our lives. Sarah's initial disbelief eventually transformed into overwhelming joy when she finally held her son in her arms. Similarly, we should remain open to the possibility that God may answer our prayers in ways that we never anticipated. We need to let go of our preconceived notions and allow God to surprise us. Thirdly, this verse underscores the importance of celebrating God's blessings and sharing our testimonies with others. Sarah's joyful declaration demonstrates her willingness to acknowledge God's role in her life and to proclaim His goodness to those around her. We too should be eager to share our stories of God's faithfulness with others, inspiring them to trust in His power and provision. Finally, this passage speaks to the power of hope. When faced with adversity, we are invited to cling to the hope of a better future. We are reminded that God is still working, still creating, and still capable of exceeding our expectations. In an increasingly cynical world, it is crucial to hold onto the hope that God's promises will be fulfilled in due time.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we thank you for your unwavering faithfulness and your ability to accomplish what seems impossible to us. Like Sarah, we often struggle to believe in your promises, especially when faced with difficult circumstances. Forgive us for our doubt and help us to trust in your perfect timing and your sovereign power. Grant us the strength to embrace the unexpected ways in which you may choose to work in our lives. Fill us with a sense of awe and wonder at your boundless creativity and your unfailing love. May we be bold in sharing our testimonies of your goodness with others, inspiring them to place their hope in you. Help us to cling to the hope of a brighter future, knowing that you are always working behind the scenes to bring about your perfect plan. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: Sarah's doubt stemmed from her advanced age and long history of barrenness. Years had passed since God's initial promise, and the physical reality seemed to contradict His word. This caused her to initially laugh at the thought of conceiving.

faqs.answer: Genesis 21:7 marks a pivotal point in fulfilling the Abrahamic covenant. Isaac's birth is the long-awaited beginning of Abraham's promised numerous descendants who would bless all nations.
